Topic.Title: Dow will go down 275 today

Message.Msg: guidance was given based on Euro @ 1.29 to 1.00 dollar. Now in Europe, if Euro falls to say 1.20 Euro to 1.00 dollar, that hurts Mcdonalds because guidance was given at 1.29, since MCD does not hedge currencies, this causes less revenue and less income. Most MCD supplies are shipped from Regional Areas, for Example, Spain MCD receive supplies from and or near spain vs say Malta, which receives supplies from Italy. If Burgers and fries are priced in Euros in Europe Mcdonalds estimates those sales at 1.29 (where they gave guidance) but since the Euro was 1.29-1.21 for the quarter or average prices of 1.23 (since it slid from 1.27 to 1.24 real fast) Mcdonalds thus registered less dollar earnings. I hope you understand now. If reverting back to 1.29 guidance, MCD would have beat by a nickel. Conversely when the Euro climbs, MCD benefits in earnings from greater dollar revenue.

Topic.Title: Let me get this strait. If amzn beats earnings by a penny,

Message.Msg: You do realize that even with a $0.04 beat their PE Ratio will still skyrocket from 180 to 275. They will be replacing Q2 2011 earnings of $0.42 with $.04. Amazon's first to market advantage is gone and they are playing catch up now. They are looking at major capital expenditures over the next year to build out warehouses to catch Walmart and tablets/phones to catch Apple. The Price to Earnings ratio compression is coming when investors realize that Amazon is no longer "The Player", but has to ramp up spending to be a player.

The first post you responded to is complete BS: AMZN couldn't earn $7/shr in it's dreams: stock price jumped the shark on earnings going from $2.52 to $1.21 bu the WS buy story on the sstock is intact. Great to be a CEO like Bezos where what you earn matters little after 17 years.

Topic.Title: Let me get this strait. If amzn beats earnings by a penny,

Message.Msg: how do you see it? 352 target was based on simple 20% + 5%, The $7 in earnings was based on CAPEX spending for growth, last year, that $7 assumes 0 in earnings other than CAPEX, really it should be $400 or more. Besides, after discounting 15% from the conservative 352 target, I get about $300, still higher than here and still priced to 85% perfection on a slightly conservative basis. AMZN is cheap, if you have a hard time figuring that out then do yourself a favor and buy GE or better yet, HD. Best wishes to everyone!

Topic.Title: Let me get this strait. If amzn beats earnings by a penny,

Message.Msg: It will remain a complete mystery to me why and better yet how does amzn continue to get its special 'PE' expemption status on razor thin declining margins and declining profits.

Topic.Title: Let me get this strait. If amzn beats earnings by a penny,

Message.Msg: don't short it based on the PE: that's big mistake.

Topic.Title: Let me get this strait. If amzn beats earnings by a penny,

Message.Msg: cap ex for sales growth with no earnings: capex are balance sheet items: not income statement items: only in depreciation of the capitlzed assets: I'll agree with you on one point: the stock is being priced on growth: sales and cash flow being taken in, not on $7 earnings they won't ever make.

Topic.Title: Shorts, are you sad?

Message.Msg: It is sad that the float manipulation scam leads to such massive malinvestment and misallocation of resources. But, all those who perpetuated these games will have their tail handed to them soon over the next year. Amazon can introduce 12 devices for all I care. The Google and Apple edosystems will dwarf it. The highest margin, highest ROIC part of the business will be LOSING share in a significant way (and AMZN can say Fire users consume however much more digital content its wants... still doesn't change the fact that the installed base of iOS and Android devices is 10X larger and they gap is growing...). As Google really starts to get after Amazon, it will lose its FCF leverage to attack bricks and mortar. It will have wasted immense money building out redundant infrastructure, only to fall well short of being able to offer a meaningful system wide/nationwide increased service level... Meanwhile, a resurgent eBay also be stepping up the competition for Amazon. Shorts, don't be stupid, These usually go through a capitulation squeeze phase like we just saw with CMG. If you have excessive leverage (cannot maintain the position at 33% higher prices for a year), you will likely get taken out. You might get lucky, but you are more likely to lose...

Topic.Title: Shorts, are you sad?

Message.Msg: Somebody isn't. Huge block short today. Real money from a serious player. Almost too big to be a short hedge fund. I suspect we will have a "Breakout" to test shorts pain threshold. The ironic thing is the real money to be made is in testing long's pain threshold. All of the complacent longs are used to the other side feeling pain. If the algos switch their focus and test the downside to trigger stop losses, there will be a lot more volatility and thus money to be made for traders on the downside... Either way, doesn't matter to me. I'm patient. Happy to ride it up and make more as I did with CMG.

Message.Title: If bearish, buy puts, don't short
Message.Msg: If you are bearish, the puts aren't too expensive (lower premiums than CMG puts before it crashed). They can't squeeze you out of puts. And there is a chance of a delicious CMG-like plunge. (Had 100-fold gains on CMG puts). If you want to play it safe, buy put spreads (but will limit the profit if you are correct).

Topic.Title: Don't bet against Einhorn

Message.Msg: I wouldn't short Apple, with its sub 15 PE. If anything, I would buy calls on Apple and buy puts (or put spreads) on 170 PE Amazon. Einhorn likes Apple and dislikes Amazon.

Topic.Title: If bearish, buy puts, don't short

Message.Msg: More importantly, DO NOT BUY SHORT TERM PUTS. They can ALWAYS hold it up for a short period of time. Make them hold this into 2013. Make the longs risk Congressional dysfunctionality and increased capital gains taxes. Make them take the risk of a fiscal cliff induced drop in GDP of 5% (in other words big recession). Make them take the risk that consumers won't shift purchase behavior to more local once the sales tax playing field is level. All that is a 2013 issue. You might get lucky with near term options, but you are more likely to lose money, especially if you go all in. LT puts. Not weekly. Not monthly. When folks start thinking long term, this will get less attractive. It's enterprise value is nearly equal to that of Google, which has $50B in cash and generates nearly $15B A YEAR. Google will be using that cash to compete more directly with AMZN over the next year (Google Apps and Drive to compete with AWS, Android/Nexus devices with Google Play Content cannibalizing AMZN digital content sales, more to come) and AMZN will struggle in to generate the cash to realize its vision in a recessionary environment. (Side note, I REALLY hope GOOG buys RIMM to accelerate/strengthen its enterprise offering to create pain for AWS, plus it has tons of relevant IP to thwart AAPL and MSFT). This scam will come to an end. I strongly doubt it will end with thus earnings release, especially because people seem to be piling on. It backfired on Baidu today...

I would not expect a CMG type reaction, but at least a 5-10% drop.

Topic.Title: Revenues ???

Message.Msg: Edison: Kindle and ebooks have been a cash cow for AMZN. But, the installed base of iOS (iTunes) and Android (Google Play) devices OUTSIDE the AMZN Kindle/eBook ecosystem has gone exponential. With the cloud offerings, rapidly growing catalogs (and publisher's desire for competition in distribution to capture more economic rents for themselves), Amazon is seeing significant erosion in its source of greatest competitive advantage. It is also losing a structural consumer price advantage (uncollected sales taxes) that it has enjoyed for the past two decades... Think of that as AMZN having just passed peaked margins (because all else being equal, AMZN will have to sell for less to maintain the same price based consumer value proposition) and peak distinctiveness... I'll address the local warehouse /same day delivery stuff later. Scaling laws will prove to be different than experienced to date...

Message.Title: Do not buy weekly or monthly puts
Message.Msg: Folks: This is massively overextended. But, if you buy short term puts, you are simply enabling the big boys to keep it afloat by giving them a weekly income stream (a continuous flow of new energy to keep it aloft). Do not buy short dated puts. Yes, the time premium is more significant out a few months. So, go deep in the money ($260-280) and out to October minimum (gives you another earnings report) and buy those. Into 2013 is even safer. Most importantly, don't buy more contracts than you can carry for a year at prices 33% higher than today (that's ultimately what I had to do to beat CMG). I speak from experience -- it can be a painful ride so be prepared for it to be long and arduous. If it drops sooner, so be it. You'll still make plenty of money. But, understand that they way the market works now is to make you capitulate and eat your winners. It's easy for the big boys to do when you over extend (whether via shorts on margin or too many short term put contracts). I've found the added expense of LT DITM forces me to treat it with the same prudence as a short...

Message.Msg: Buying weekly and monthly puts worked spectacularly for Chipotle bears last week! What is Amazon is the next Cramer pump to crash?

Topic.Title: Superhigh PE gig is up

Message.Msg: 100/170 x $228 = $134. What price give AMZN at PE of 50 (3 times Apple's)? 50/170 x $228 = $67. Split the difference: PE of 75 yields price of $100. My downside target is $100/share.
